Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2007 02:23AM Jennifer wrote: If you are in the begining stages of treatment/wrapping then in order to get the best results you will need to wrap. It gets real frustrating in the begining trying to get everything just right but please try. There are a couple post here about wrapping, maybe that will help. As far as the Jovi Pak you need to be seen by a fitter and she needs to take certain measurements and then complete the paper work and send the information to the manufacturer. My insurance company pays 90 % for my sleeves. I don't know the time frame for a Jovi Pak by my Reid Sleeve took 4 weeks to get and my Tribute took two weeks to get. I also have custom daytime sleeves as well and I need measurements from the fitter to be done for these as well and they take about 2 weeks to get. Unforunately with all the sleeves and such it's not a matter of small, medium, or large.  It's an individual thing. Hope this helps some. Maybe Binney or NPAT will be by soon and add more.

Posts.Title: How do you define stable in regards to our arms with lymphedema Jennifer purple32

Posts.Content: Jennifer wrote: Looks, size, feel, measurements from a fitter or PT? How long should it take the arm to become stable, stay stable? I did 9 months of PT changed PT's, was released, went back and forth to the first after reconstructive surgeries and then back to check the arm.  How many have their arms go back to pre-lymphedema size? How many people never get back to pre-lymphdema size (except me)? According to Solaris my arm measurements (up to the time this new fitter took over 12/11) were consistant/stable. Now I am second guessing myself and every thing these days. It is getting frustrating at best. I do not want to go back to PT - they want to wrap indefinately using no foam or padding. I have an area that flares and love and need a good fitting night sleeve. New fitter will not order night sleeve w/o paper work doctor can not supply. Can't go back to old fitter(s). I am stuck, frustrated and don't know what to do or where to turn. Family does not understand. I am not giving up the fight about my sleeves but it wears a person down. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: How do you define stable in regards to our arms with lymphedema Jennifer purple32

Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2007 08:20PM Jennifer wrote: I went for many months. Was taught MLD, how to bandage with compression bandages and some stretches/exercises. At first it was three times a week, then two, then once a week. I was able to get arm mobility back and a slight reduction. At this point I had been going on a regular basis for many months. I was interested in making a switch to a sleeve for daytime use and I was not getting good feed back from the PT so my oncologist told me to try the PT at the hospital. I did and she showed me how to wrap with foam, did MLD, set me up using the pump with them, also did MLD. After about 3 months she measured me for a daytime and night time sleeves. She also set me up with the fitter where I would be getting my sleeves and future sleeves as well. At this point I had more reduction in my arm. So since I had the basics down and that I knew what I was doing so there really was no need for me to coming. She said the reason for coming was for me to learn how to take care of my arm. So from the first PT to the hospital PT I was going to PT for almost a year, although I took a break for a couple months over the summer. I did/do go back from time to time for various reasons and just to stay in contact. I did not see total reduction of my arm and some of us don't. A month is not very long for them to be asking you.

Posts.Title: Did you self-dx your LE or who did? sccruiser andys

Posts.Content: Jennifer wrote: I have been in and out of treatment several times in the last 3 years since diagnosis of breast cancer and lymphedema. The first time was for 9 months in which I wrapped day and night. I do get some reduction but not much and most of it comes from when I wear my reid sleeve. I massage daily and keep my arm moisturized. Wrap or wear a reid sleeve to bed, and wear my juzo sleeve during the day, and take the neccesary precautions. My arm which is my dominant right arm is still much larger then the other side - beetween the wrist and elbow. Even though is is bigger I can get it soft. I have been to two different lymphedema places, the first place for the first 9 months and then at the hospital out patient for another 3 months. The hospital is who fitted me for a reid sleeve and juzo sleeve. But they also released me once they knew I had the massage routine down. I had gone back to the first place several times either for what I consided a check-up a couple of times and then for ROM and fascia release after different phases of reconstruction. Each time they would also help with my arm too. I can't live in PT going all the time. I do the best I can and try to be very careful. I have had no further complications a side from an occassional achy arm in which I elevate and baby it when it gets this way. But my arm is stil much larger and I often read where many of you have had significant or complete reduction of your arms. I want to know your secrets. Please anyone? Jennifer Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2007 06:39PM Jennifer wrote:
Posts.Title: LE and depression rrs rrs

Posts.Content: Jennifer wrote: So my new fitter seems to be working out for the most part. My Solaris night sleeve seems good. I do notice when my arm is not as full I do not see as deep of a pattern. But a fuller arm or freshly washed sleeve I see more of a pattern. Now my first day sleeve (medi-mondi) seemed too tight and too short. When ordering and measuring the fitter asked about trying an oblique fitted sleeve with the silcone band inside instead of the top. Well the sleeve ended up being too tight and seemed to slide down my arm. So we remeasure (measurements pretty consistant/stable) and order the new sleeve adding one centimeter to the length, going back with the normal fit (I think) and having the silicone band on the top of the sleeve. Well I was happy with the longer sleeve but the fitter insisted it is too long. But she told me to wear the sleeve and wash each night for about five days. The first few days every thing was going well and I loved the fit and the lower arm where my LE is at was maintaing a consist size by the end of the day, yea me - lol. But about day four the sleeve is bunching or gathering on the outter part of my upper arm mostly near the silicone band. It's a slight bunch or puckering and I feel as if I have to keep pulling the sleeve up per say. I was doing a lot of moving and organizing but don't think this should have mattered. So I just spoke to my fitter and we are going to send this one back to adjust the length by the one centimeter but leave the fit and band the same. I am a little nervous about this because the bunching is slight but the length seems good. Okay so I look at pictures on line at how day sleeves should and should not look. The above sleeve looked like the way the sleeve should fit when my arm was straight, although with a slight bend I do get some lines per say. However the more I wore the sleeve I had the bunching or puckering. Now my problems with the sleeve are only on the outter region of my sleeve with the bunching or puckering. I do not have problems per say with LE in my upper arm. I also have larger biceps then those in the pictures so I need a sleeve the goes just below the axilla (about a finger width) and not higher or lower, sort of in between the picture of the proper fit and the too short fit. This sleeve was fitting this way at first. Does any one else have this sort of problem and what have you done to help this. Oh and do sleeves shrink? My fitter tells me she is told no but she thinks they do a little. TIA. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Perfect Sleeves Finally - Almost Jennifer hugz4u

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2008 10:20PM Jennifer wrote: Thanks for the information Binney. I just thought it would be interesting to how LE is viewed in regards to the ADA. The only accomodation I would ever need would be not using my arms for the obvious of BP, IV, and other needle sticks. Now this cost nothing - not one cent and we some times still have to fight for it. Hey maybe this could be our way to get these doctors, hospitals and other medical proffessionals to honor our needs or they would be in non-compliance of the ADA. Do you think we could be on to something here? I should call and see what they say.
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer & Lymphedema & Disabilities Act Jennifer Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jennifer wrote: I have a question for those of us who live in the USA. When I was diagnoised with breast cancer I read that we are protected under the Americans with Disabilities Act as cancer patients/thrivers. So we know our lymphedema was one of the possible side affects of treatment for our breast cancer. So are we protected under the same disabilities act for lymphedema? If we are then would the medical establishments who refuse to treat our lymphedema as such actually be discriminating against us? I guess what I am getting to is things like fitting for blood draws in areas other then our at risk limbs w/o a fight or lots of pre-planning and such. I ask because I have a check up with my oncologist in May. I do believe he will want a blood draw done. But the techs will not do this from any place but the arm/hand. I will not longer allow this to be done any place but my foot or in that area after a flare up last October during a pre-surgical physical. So of course I am going to be calling my oncologist's nurse to check and have a lab slip faxed to me to have it done in an actual lab. It just at times, seems like it's never ending in advocating for ourselves for something we are entitled to regardless. Please don't take this the wrong way, I am not whinning at all I just wanted to know if anyone knows where we stand on this. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer & Lymphedema & Disabilities Act Jennifer Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2008 08:52AM Jennifer wrote: Debbie - I am wrapping because when I wrap I notice my arm is softer or I have an area where I need additional compression. See I am one of the people who after a year of PT with two separate practices with trained PT's did not have total or near total reduction of the swelling. I did have some and my arm is stable for me. So there is not much time during the course of a day or night I am not wearing my day time sleeve, wrapping in my short stretch bandages, or wear my night sleeve with the outer sleeve over it. I am measured and fitted for new daytime sleeves every 4 to 6 month or sooner if there is a fitting concern. The night time sleeves typically have a long life and can be altered by the manufacture during the life time of use. These are not typically replaced as often as the night sleeve is. bingbing - I thought the night sleeve was close to two years as well. So I guess it does sound like my night sleeve should probally be replaced soon. Debbie do you wear your swell spots under your day time sleeve as well? I wonder if this would help having the padding day and night. I just do not want to return to the bulky dough boy look of all the bulky padding and the half hour wrapping schedule.

Posts.Content: Jennifer wrote: Just got my new night time sleeve. My fitter showed me how to put it on and how to put the outter sleeves (2) on. It was a little snug but not tight when she showed me. Same thing later that evening when I put it on. Fast forward to today (3 rd day) and it seems almost too loose/comfortable . This is the sleeve and the outter sleeves. I do use a slippy and wear a rubber glove when putting it all on also (fitter did the same thing). I am also concerned about the outter sleeves covering my thumb as well. I am pretty sure my arm size was the same when I was measured and when it came in. I know some of you have this same sleeve (which is so easy, maybe too easy) and was wondering how your experiences with it were. I am going to call the fitter and see what she says too. I can't believe this sleeve has made that much difference in that little bit of time. By the way not that it makes a difference I also got my new daytime sleeve as well. Now of course I would love to believe that all this is finally working but I think it is too good to be true. Any thoughts? Jen Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: tribute sleeve concerns Jennifer Jennifer

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2007 02:20AM Jennifer wrote: Binney I talked to Stephanie where they made my sleeve. She told me to wear it for a week and then see. She wants me to do some measurements on my arm and first see if the sleeve is actually reducing my arm. She said I should make sure I have the nice little pattern on my arm in the morning, which I do. If the sleeve is working really well and I am getting arm reduction so soon or even if it just needs an adjustment they want me to go back to my fitter to be measured again and then to send my sleeve out to be altered. I did get 2 CD's in the mail today with a warranty card to send back. For some reason they were not included when my sleeve was sent to the fitter. My fitter ordered two outter sleeves for convenience. I think I am going to wash it this week and see how it fits after washing it as well. I just bought a can of tennis balls for the dryer. I hope this sleeve is working because it is so much easier then the reid and circaid and of course less time consuming then wrapping. Here we go to a fitter who has to be a durable medical something or another. Most PT's here don't do the measuring for garments. But then again some PT's think wrapping is the key. I'm all for that when I first started but not 4 years later.

Posts.Title: When do you replace a night sleeve Jennifer OneBadBoob

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2007 08:39PM Jennifer wrote: With the exception of the bio-concepts sleeves most custom sleeves are a heavier weight fabric. That's sort of good because many of us needing the traditional custom sleeves need it because we may not see complete reduction of our lymphedema so we need something a little more durable.  We have a new normal of our arm so to speak. The bad part is the measuring, cost (if insurance doesn't cover it), waiting to get it and then the fact that it can be so darn hot to wear in the warmer months. Although much better then the banadges. My insurance company has not said anything about my custom day or night sleeves. I have had Juzo custom day time sleeves and did not like them at all. Now I have an Elvarex by Jobst and it is much better. I currently have a Solaris Tribute night sleeve as well sleeve. Much more comfortable and easier to use then the two previous Reid sleeves and the Circaid night sleeve. My insurance company has been good about everything so far. I do need to use a DME. I like mine but there are times where I think I need to find another just to make sure. Even though my night sleeve is more convenient I still will wrap on occasion. But I have to get those bandages just so or I find I am rewrapping in the middle of the night. Not a good thing at all.

Posts.Content: Jennifer wrote: A couple months ago I found out that my first fitter (who was promoted) left the company and started her own. Now she was well trained and used this to her benefit. Well I found her by accident. I had her measure for new sleeves. I also asked her if she could send back my night sleeve because it just never really fit the way I thought it should. I knew the one year mark was coming up and after that I would have to pay for the adjustment. So she called them and they said yes. After a paperwork issue I got my newly altered night sleeve back and I have come to the conclusion it was not right at all before this. Now it fits like a glove per say. Before it was like an old worn sock. I have learned to go else where when you are not happy and take advantage of those warranties and deadlines. Oh and by the way after umm sleeping late and having my sleeve on for oh 10 to 12 hours my arm was almost the size of the other arm w/o LE. Log in to post a reply

I am leaving the blister alone, but I am thinking since it doesn't burn any more it would be safe to put some antibiotic ointment on it and watch it. It doesn't look swollen, although this thumb has arthritis in it and I can't straighten it all the way - never could since the arthritis set in. I have already had a tetnus shot this year so I am good there. I need to call my doctor Monday for an appointment for something unrelated and was going to see if she would look at it as well. Anything else I should do, I was thinking about covering it now to keep it clean, but I am not sure. Jennifer Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2007 02:41PM Jennifer wrote: Thanks for the links Binney. I come and read here mostly because it seems to be the most up to date. I find I can also look back and read if I have something simlar come up. I just am not sure what and how to go about dealing with all of this. Posts.Title: I am doing everything they tell me not to do to prevent LE... brando She

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2008 05:14AM Jennifer wrote: You know when I was talking to my doctor today I actually looked him in the eye and told him unless I am unconsious and can not speak for myself then I will not subject either arm. I told him one arm is compromised and I have to protect the other arm. That was when he was insistant about the BP. But I find this very interesting because I went to an urgent care place this weekend because I ended up with an offical case of the flu. The very young looking nurse comes in with her blood pressure machine on wheels and I told her no. I told her I had lymphedema and she could not use my arms. She looked puzzled so I briefly told her is she needs a BP it would need to be done on my thigh or ankle, but I would need to lie down and have my legs elevated for about 5 minutes. She was still puzzled but ask me to lie down and said she would be back. She did return and then asked me how she was supposed to take my blood pressure on my ankle. I told her just like on my arm. She had no problem at all and the reading seemed pretty close for me. Now this young looking nurse learned something from me a patient she may not even see again. She did not give me a hard time at all. Maybe this nurse should educate the doctor I am about to leave. I think maybe I should carry a handout or something. Oh my husband and mil both have decided to leave the practice as well. Seems the doctor gets a little po'd if you seek treatment with a specialist for other conditions. My mil, fil, sil, and husband all are diabetic. The doctor was upset with my inlaws when they informed him that they were going to arranging their care with a specialist. Too bad because my husband did too. I think my doctor does need an education for sure. He no longer makes hospital rounds but I am sure he needs to be educated as to why he will be loosing patients. I think the letter to the insurance company is a good ideal. Thanks fo letting me vent I was truley frustrated today and was not going to give in.  I wonder if his wife were to be in my shoes what he would tell her.
Posts.Title: Frustration With Doctor and Use of Non-Affected Arm Jennifer Alyson

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2013 01:16AM - edited Jan 15, 2013 08:07PM by Jennifer Yes this is a custom sleeve. This was a remake because the first one had an internal silicone band (making it shorter) and an obilique cut which had the silicone band on the top of the arm but not the in the axilla area. That sleeve was too tight and too short. My clothes kept puling in further down. We did a remake (remeasured as well) to this sleeve shown. I asked for the additional length (one centimeter) because we were not sure about where the band would be place (sewn in the top or attached to the top). When the sleeve came in my fitter did say she thought it was too long. But since it felt better (thent he previous one) she agreed to let me wear and wash it and then call her back after five days to let her know that how it was fitting. I called her today and she was more then happy to have me return it to her so we can get it resized. I am going to call her back again tomorrow to see if we can't remeasure again since the sleeve is going back. I did print the pictures so my fitter will have those to send back with the sleeve as well. I am going to start a new thread to see if others will post pictures on how their sleeves fit too. I have been wearing sleeves for almost 9 years now and I have never had this much problem getting them to fit. This is a new fitter and she seems to be good, although does like to try to sell other items, but I am not buying - lol.

Posts.Content: Jennifer wrote: I have been here over the years posting a lot more in the begining and then popping in from time to time, posting some and reading more. My LE started in 2002 after a mastectomy and node dissection.  I have been through PT between about 5 or 6 therapist at two different practices/clinics. I learned MLD and went from wrapping, wrapping with foam and then to sleeves - although it took about a year to to get to the sleeves. Now my arm has never returned to the pre-LE size and my problem area is the forearm above the wrist to the elbow, including the elbow. But I have tried to keep the swelling down and eliminate the fullness feeling.   Any way I am finding the I am needing to do more as I seem to be having a flare up. I know how to wrap (of course need to order more/new supplies). Am working with a new fitter with a new night sleeve that was sent back with the thumb/hand area too short once already. She said technically I was too far out of the two week time period (about 4 to 6 weeks since I picked it up, although could not wear it for another two weeks due to a recent revision surgery) but she would contact the supplier to see how they could help as I have had the last 4 night sleeves made by the supplier and could not actually wear the sleeve. She also feels the area should be longer as well. So there you have it. My short version of what has been happening. I have been reading the MB here and it seems there is a lot for me to catch up on. Here is were I turn to those who maybe able help - please...TIA Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Some help/reassurance please Jennifer Tina337

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2013 12:20AM - edited Jul 15, 2013 12:20AM by Jennifer I am considering going to something different next time for a night sleeve as well. My insurance company will pay for one night sleeve each year, well after deductible and co pays.. I just had my tribute altered. I never took advantage of the free alteration in the past and my sleeve was loose and was not working as well as it should have. It feels odd since just getting it back. Feels snugger, they also altered my outer sleeve as well. The first night I had to take it off half way through the night. The next night I was fine. I don't know what happened last night but I woke up with sausage fingers, my arm ached and I had a pocket of fluid around my elbow. My sleeve goes from hand to axilla (no fingers - just thumb) and until last night it has never been a problem. I am hoping it was just to over exertion and the heat and humidity yesterday.
Posts.Title: Solaris Tribute - replacement options Sher KittyDog

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2009 11:56PM Jennifer wrote: I developed LE within the same week after a mastecomy with node dissection - I previously had a lumpectomy with 2 SN's removed and had no problems. Nevertheless I now have LE. I didn't know if I want reconstruction so at first so I waited. After my pathology report I decided to have a prophylatric mastectomy on the other side after completing chemo. A year later I made the choice to do bilateral LAT flaps with an expander. My LE did not get any worse. After more then a year at trying to get my new breast mounds at least into two actual breast mounds I changed PS's and started over again. This time with a DIEP Flap. I am happy to say I am finally done with reconstruction. This time around still my LE stayed stable as well. Through out my surgeries and chemo I was back and forth for sessons of PT, not the entire time but a few different times to help with the LE, range of motion, or the tightness of the scars. I do need to wear a bra and found a couple wonderful bras that I wear. Eventually I may have the choice of wearing a bra or not. However right now I am in the process of massaging scars and such and a bra feels better during the day. It keeps my new breast contained per say so it reduces the weight of them on my healing scars. My only regret was not finding my current PS sooner. There are no guarantees with LE and surgery of any kind. So I would say there is no right or wrong answer. It's a personal choice. Good luck with your decisons.

Posts.Title: Some help/reassurance please Jennifer Tina337

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2007 12:57AM Jennifer wrote: Well I didn't exactly have a chance to not do what I wasn't supposed to. I had a lumpectomy and SNB (2 lymph nodes) and then needed a mastectomy and node dissection (18 more lymph nodes) three weeks later. Within the first few days after the mastectomy my arm swelled so bad I could not move it. When I had my drains taken out approximately a week after surgery the NP at my breast surgeons office gave me a referral to a lymphedema therapist. When I called I told her I had a little swelling. She purposely scheduled me for a Saturday in order to get me in asap before the holidays. She was shocked to see my little swelling which was major. This was about 4 years ago. I still have lymphedema (yes right hand and dominant hand). Now I am as careful as I can be with the other side (prophylactic mastectomy with SNB - 3 nodes). I am also careful with my LE side as well and try to follow a routine. I am now concerend about the other side and decided to see PT because she has that sides measurements from when I first started. I don't have the swelling in the other side just a weid feeling, the feeling of fullness, and sometimes achiness. But then it goes away and all is fine. But I want to make sure. Binney I have read the position papers but I sort of am not sure who came across the information and how. I also get confused as to the different LE forums as it seems like there are older posts and more on leg LE.. Jennifer
Posts.Title: I am doing everything they tell me not to do to prevent LE... brando She

Posts.Content: Jennifer wrote: I am in love with this sleeve because I can wear it all night. I do see the sleeve working in the pattern on my lower arm below my elbow where 90% of my swelling is. But not too much above my elbow and after about 4/5 days or so the pattern on my lower arm is not as prevalent so I wash and dry according to directions - although my front loading dryer doesn't like tennis balls. So is this typical - the stretching/fit? I did talk to the compnay and they did tell me to wear and monitor the arm. Guess I should start measuring too. They did say they would do the first alteration free and I would have my sleeve back within a week. Just seems like the upper arm was not snug enough from the begining. I'm afraid that it will wear out too soon from all the washing but how I so hate to be without it even for a week. Oh by the way the power sleeve is showing white elastic around the seam - this can't be good. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Non LE Arm Fullness... Jennifer Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jennifer wrote: I am just so frustrated. I really like our family doctor but he just does not understand and gives me a hard time about BP and blood draws. I already have LE in my right arm which happened with in days after surgery. The left arm is fine, for now. I say this because in October I had what I thought could be the start of LE. I had some blood work and BP done using this arm. Well I knew I could be taking a risk but didn't really want to believe it. Any way within a few hours my arm started to ache, I also noticed some swelling. Was I imagining it this? No After 5 years of dealing with LE I would like to think I know when I see something not typical for me. I did MLD and elevated my arm. Then I called my PT and made an appointment to have things checked out. Thankfully no signs where present. Anyway I have managed to have BP done else where (ankle/thigh) at other providers offices. I have managed to have an IV done in my foot/ankle for surgery. So today I go to the doctor (GP) because I had a few elevated blood levels in Ocotber when I had blood done during a pre-surgical physical. So I return a few months later like my doctor asked me. I purposely did not fast because I knew he would pressure me and I wanted to use the lab that will do blood draws using my foot. We had a coversation with him remarking that a simple rubber band (the tounequet) would not cause a problem. I told him I didn't think so until the last time and then explained to him. He tried to brush it off. He then asked about BP and I told him my thigh or ankle can and have been used. He said there is no proof they are true numbers. Maybe or maybe not, but if it regularly done then we would see what's normal for me. I made it very clear that I already have limitations on my right arm and did not want to pose a risk for the left arm. Of course when he writes the lab slip I had to ask him to note from foot. He did so reluctantly. It is just so frustrating to feel like I need to fight him each time I go in. I think it may be time to start checking for a new doctor, one who will be willing to work with me. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jennifer wrote: So I have a new fitter with a different company. I was measured and fitted. Sleeves (Mediven Mondi Day Sleeve and Solaris Tribute Night Sleeve) came in and seemed to fit upon trying them on. But after wearing them for about three days (washing the day sleeve daily). Something just didn't seem right. The day sleeve slipped and bunched at the elbow. It also does not seem to come high enough on my arm. The night sleeve seems loose in the hand and upper arm. So the fitter remeasured and ordered me a new day sleeve, adjusting the length by one cm. As well as a different type band. I hope this works. One cm just does not seem to be much. The night sleeve is odd as it seems as there is no affect or pattern on my hand but there is a pattern on my thumb. There is a pattern on my lower arm and it is gradual and fades as it goes up my arm. Now I wash the night sleeve weekly but after about the third day the pattern is less noticeable on the lower arm and almost non existent on the upper arm. The fitter tells me there should be no pattern on my hand or thumb. She told me not to have the sleeve snug against the web of my thumb and had me put on my sleeve to show me how it should be worn. I did this last night and it didn't make any difference. It's been a long time since I had a good fitting set of sleeves so I am doubting myself and the fit of the sleeves. I know Solaris will make the night sleeve right but I just do not want to go through another year of this. Can others comment and share the fitting of their sleeves please. TIA. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Day Sleeves - Fit Jennifer GottaloveNED

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2013 08:25PM - edited Jan 15, 2013 08:31PM by Jennifer Kira, This sleeve was sort of a trial and error. Both the fitter and I made a mistake in the length. My last sleeve was too short and too tight so we had it remade and my fitter was not sure how the band would be (sew into the top and be part of the sleeve or onto and be in addition to the sleeve because we were chaging from an oblique fit to a standard fit). Turns out it was sewn onto so that silicone band plus the one centimeter addition resulted in the sleeve being too big and bunching. The sleeve seems almost perfect below the elbow where 80% of my swelling is. See I can't be a simple measurement and can't wear my sleeve all the way to axilla because of a some what thicker axilla area (well compared to most) due to my first attempt at reconstruction being not so good and my lat muscle and scaring still in that region. Good news is I had the reconstruction undone and redone, this time DIEP. It's much better but like I said the lat muscle and the additional scar tissue is still in the general region so a sleeve needs to be a happy medium, not too low but not all the way up to the axilla region. My (new) fitter is very receptive into making things right and I have faith as I have learned that my fitter has other (happy) patients on the MB. I love the learning and looking out for one another on this MB.
Posts.Title: Pictures of new sleeve on my arm Jennifer LindaKR

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2012 01:19PM Jennifer wrote: GottaloveNED, I just left a message for the fitter asking her to hold off on having the day sleeve remade. I kept thinking about the one cm. It is not enough. I made the mistake of wearing the first make of the new sleeve today and fluid backed up into my forearm and into my hand and fingers. I took the sleeve off and did some work on my arm to move the fluid and then decided to just wear my old sleeves until I can get an appointment with the fitter. I have an odd situation with my arm. See I don't need a sleeve or gauntlet. With a well fitting sleeve I have no problem with my hand or fingers. My PT also told me my forearm is longer then most people so she has to add a measurement when she does her measuring. I have used "It Stays" but had a skin reaction to it and ended up with cellulitis. So I decided it was something I would not use again as I didn't want to risk it.

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2010 05:22AM Jennifer wrote: I get allergy shots in my thighs. I typically get a local reaction on one or sometimes both of my thighs resulting in a hot, swollen and itchy bump the size of a grape or sometimes literally a 1/2 of a ping pong ball - think sliced in half. I just didn't want to chance it. My doctor and the nurses giving the shots have no problem with it. Matter of fact I am often asked if any new nurses or those doing an internship (with supervison) can do my shots. I have no problems at all.   My right arm has LE - mastectomy and node dissection. Left arm prophylactic mastectomy and SNB.

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2013 03:00PM Jennifer wrote: I think I am the exception to the rule as a glove made my hand swell. I wear a custom sleeve and was measured and fitted for several gloves with the same results. So far things have gone well, although I know things can change. Now I just got my 4th sleeve since December 2012. First one was too short and the silicone was only partial. Second one was way too long and I posted pictures of it on this thread. The next one came in and was too short again. So I decided to check with a different location/fitter with the current company. They had the local sleeve rep from Medi and a second one come in from out of state to check the sleeve and measure my arm. Well it was too short, so they measured my arm several times in a couple different ways. I was given a business card by the local rep and told to call any time there is a concern. So I picked up my new sleeve today and we will see how things go as it fit like a glove at first but I am a little concerned about the length and the elbow region. I wore the sleeve for several hours and took it off and it is irritated and red in the elbow region. The redness is going away gradually and it is most likely because I have been wearing older stretched out sleeves and this is a new sleeve. So hoping for the best and will ease into wearing the new sleeve a little longer each day.

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2012 07:59PM Jennifer wrote: Kira yes correct code. The nurse filled out the code and used the doctors notes but they only indicated arm edema. But the fitter wants written documentation of the oncologist diagnosis and the word "lymphedema" in the last office visit notes. The oncologist didn't diagnos it the breast surgeon did nearly 10 years ago when she sent me to the PT. I stopped at her office today to get the visit notes from a visit last week which did indicate I had "lymphedema" and wore a sleeve. Not sure if this would be enough because there is no code in the office visit. I am also not sure why the fitter needs to know all of my medical history and my recent office visit. Seems like an invasion of privacy to me. I could have been discussing private matters that have to do with the after affects of breast cancer and nothing to do with lymphedema.  I do have a call into the PA at the breast surgeon but her office is not good with this sort of thing so that's why I go to my oncologist. I have an appointment with my primary care doctor Monday for something else so I am not sure he would even want to get involved. My next step would be the PT but they don't believe in sleeves, they expect patients to wrap iindefinately and w/o foam or padding. Which I truely believe did more harm then good for me. The second PT is out patient at the hospital. I guess I could call them but by the time I get an appointment my measurements would be off. I wish it was just about a form looking for a signature but that is not good enough. I have made two trips to the fitter now, the new fitter is an hour one way. I just don't where else to turn.
Posts.Title: fitter and doctor delaying sleeves Jennifer Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jul 16, 2009 12:15AM Jennifer wrote: Ok someone is giving you the run around. I was admitted to the hospital last week. I needed to have a blood draw and the iv stopped allowing blood flow. I told the nurses and the doctor right there no they could not stick me any other place but my foot. The doctor told the nurse so do it. She said it's been a long time and she would need him to write the orders. He stopped and did the blood draw right there. Yes the doctor did the blood draw in the hospital right in my room. He went a little further then my foot above my ankle but in the front. Ouch! He said if moore blood is needed then have them draw a little lower so it won't be so painful. But doctors can and should take over in a situation like this. Breast cancer and the complcations that are involved with it are part of the disibility act and we are protected so I wonder if refusing to accomadate us for this would be discrimination? Something to think about.  Be careful with MRI's or CT's with contrast. A larger needle is often needed for the contrast so be prepared for a little more discomfort then the norm when inserting it int he foot/hand.
Posts.Title: How to get a foot draw? moogie TNBCWarrior19

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2008 03:03AM Jennifer wrote: Thanks for the reminders everyone. I need all the help I can get some days. Right now I have decided to wrap a few night a week to see if I can work on some swelling around my elbow. Might be adding foam or a swell spot too. The book mentioned has a lot if information in it. I got this several years back. I think they may have updated portions of it. Does anyone know if it addresses the issue of those of us at risk or with LE on both sides? Okay now please don't gasp at this. But I have found when shaving my legs in the shower if I turn the shower head to the relaxing massage I am moving around enough to actually get the back portion of my MLD. It probally should not be used in place of MLD on a regular basis but hey every few days it works well with not too much pressure.  Dating the banadages so we know when to replace them is a great ideal. I started doing this a few years back. By the way if you are using a night sleeve it never hurts to have a set of current bandages on hand.  I try (but have been a little too lax) to wrap when I need to wash the night sleeve. This way the night sleeve can dry overnight and I can keep current with my wrapping skills. This also tends to soften my arm even more so. By the way when I stop at traffic lights or wait my turn at the bank or yes fast food place I also tend to clear the neck and under arm areas and sometimes even the groin area - hey no one can see me and I don't care if they could - lol. If it works for me then that's what counts. Some days I do this several times a day for an extra benefit. Oh and with the warmer weather here I drink a lot more decaf iced tea. When drinking coke it's also decaf when possible as well. I have heard/read that caffeine in large amounts is not good for LE. I wish we didn't have so much humidity. But it's par for the course here in Maryland. So I try to keep one of the red plastic slippie things in my car with me. See sometimes I need to remove my sleeve when out and about and need to do a mini MLD on my arm also. But the humidity makes it hard to put my sleeve back on and the slippie makes this easier. Don't forget to touch base with your therapist every now and then as well. Especially if insurance covers it you can never go wrong with a couple sessions of formal MLD. Not to mention they are a source of information. Jennifer

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2012 10:59AM Jennifer wrote: Kira this is a new fitter. The claim has not even been sent because they wanted the additional information from the doctor and what he sent does not seem to be enough for them. I talked to the insurance company twice now and both times they said they do not need the additional information. The RX from the doctor with the diagnosis code is enough. The fitter says this is their company policy. The previous two fitters developed this policy a few years ago as well however they excepted what the doctor sent and there was no hold up. The fitter did now say they would have the day sleeve made because the doctors notes would now work for those. But they will not make the night sleeve with those notes unless I leave my credit card with them. They are worried about the doctors notes and the fact I already had a night sleeve made and returned/claim being voided. Telling me my insurance company will not pay for my night sleeve until December because it will be a year from that time and I am only allowed to have one night sleeve a year and all this mess started last December. Once again the insurance company said no this is wrong. Even if the night sleeve was not returned the insurance company does not limit the number of sleeves (day or night) that I can get each year. Of course in the beginning of the year we have deductible to meet and the first set of sleeves can do this with no problem. But after that it is just a copay. I did get a call from the PA at the breast surgeon. She left a message telling me she thinks she can help. So I am hoping to talk to her today. The insurance company has offered to do a conference call with the fitter to get this all cleared up. It may come to this. Although not sure if the fitter will because they are telling me that my insurance company is just telling me what I want to hear. However my insurance company has never not covered any sleeve. Never denied any claim associated with my diagnosis or any thing associated with it. So this is where I hang in limbo. I do know any paper work needed I will have faxed to me and then I will fax it to the fitter. Something tells me this is the best route for the future.
Posts.Title: fitter and doctor delaying sleeves Jennifer Jennifer

Posts.Content: Jennifer wrote: I had my sleeve altered as I was about 7 months into the first year and it was starting to not work as well as it should. So my fitter measured my arm and we discovered there were changes in my arm that did warrant the sleeve to be altered. I got it back three days ago and well night one I made it half was through the night and had to take it off. The next night I was fine and made it most of the night. Last night I made it all night but woke up with sausage fingers, a sore arm and some fluids pockets around my elbow. I managed to get the the fluids to move through massage. Then put my day sleep on. Made the mistake of napping on the couch today with my day sleeve on and woke up again to sausage fingers - pretty pain full. Any way I am not sure if it is the sleeve alterations or perhaps over use and hot weather with high humidity as we set up and celebrated our daughter's engagement this weekend. I did not lift any thing too heavy. But the days and nights were long. Rest was not the best. Then the weather. The sleeve is snug and the outer jacket (which was also altered) makes it a little more snug. I can still move my arm fine. But can't do as much as I am used to doing, like holding my phone or pad to read before bed. I have to admit this sleeve feels more snug then any Tribute night sleeve that I have ever had. Any one else had a sleeve altered? I don't know if I should be worried, give it a little more time or call the fitter back and see what she says. Log in to post a reply
